page.title: 13Wildlife in Bourtie/Keithall
page.content: Game shoots are still the prerogative of the lairds of the two estates which occuply considerable acreage in the parishes of Bourtie and Keithhall/Kinkell. There is no grouse to speak of, but partridge and pheasant are killed in organized shoots in the winter months on both estates. Gamekeepers are employed to raise birds from eggs and then let them loose in summer to grow on in wild conditions before the annual slaughter. However such hand-rearing encourages other wildlife and 36 foxes are snared or shot in 12 months prior to the summer of 1984 on one estate. There are pockets of deciduous woodland and private land owned by thoher who safeguard any roaming animal which strays from the estates. Wildlife found in Bourtie has roedeer,fieldfare, corncrake,R Squirre
